Paper_1.Title: ATM mutations in hereditary pancreatic cancer patients

Evidence: Genome-wide sequencing identified heterozygous, constitutional, Ataxia Telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene mutations in two kindreds with familial pancreatic cancer.
The prevalence of ATM mutations was significantly higher in familial pancreatic cancer patients when compared with controls (4/166 vs. 0/190, Fisher’s Exact Test P=0.046).
Women with ATM mutations are at an elevated risk of breast cancer, with studies showing a cumulative lifetime risk of approximately 15-30%.
ATM mutations are implicated in increased risks of hematologic malignancies and digestive tract cancers.

Clinical_Additional_Phenotype.Phenotype: Familial aggregation of cancer types including pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas (PDAs) and breast cancer
Evidence: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas (PDAs) carry a dismal prognosis, with fewer than 5% of patients surviving 5 years.
ATM mutations in families with high rates of breast and pancreatic cancer underline its role in familial cancer syndromes.

Percentages.Pancreatic Cancer: 2.4% for familial pancreatic cancer patients with ATM mutations
Percentages.Breast Cancer: Approximately 15-30% lifetime risk for female carriers

Evidence: In our series of 166 familial pancreatic cancer probands 2.4% (4/166) carried deleterious ATM mutations.
ATM-related breast cancer risks have been reported to range from moderate to high depending on the variant detected and familial aggregation.
No evidence provided for specific management.

Recommendations: Annual MRIs for breast cancer starting at age 30 for high-risk ATM carriers.
Evidence: MRI screening protocols have been effective in early detection for ATM mutation carriers.

Frequency_of_Management.Frequency: Annual screening or as per specific cancer protocols
Evidence: Annual MRIs for high-risk breast cancer individuals, particularly ATM mutation carriers, starting in their 30s.

Age_Range_of_Management.Breast_Cancer: Starting at age 30 or earlier if family history indicates
Age_Range_of_Management.Pancreatic_Cancer: Generally age 50 or earlier in families with significant history

Comments: ATM mutations highlight a key pathway in DNA damage repair and tumor suppression, with clinical implications for therapeutic strategies.
Evidence_for_Cancer: Variants in ATM demonstrated LOH in pancreatic tumors from carriers, confirming their functional role.
Breast cancer studies link ATM to defective DNA repair pathways, influencing susceptibility to malignancies.

Therapeutic_Implications.Implications: DNA damage repair inhibitors (e.g., PARP inhibitors) may be beneficial in ATM-mutated cancers.
Evidence: Therapeutics targeting DNA repair pathways could provide a precision medicine approach for cancers associated with ATM mutations.

ACMG_Guidelines.Notes: Guidelines for inclusion of ATM mutations in gene panels for pancreatic and breast cancer should be referenced.

Paper_2.Title: Rare variants in the ATM gene and risk of breast cancer

Evidence: Recent studies have confirmed that some specific variants in the ATM gene are associated with increased breast cancer risk.
The risk estimates from this study suggest that women carrying the pathogenic variant, ATM c.7271T>G, or truncating mutations demonstrate a significantly increased risk of breast cancer.

Clinical_Additional_Phenotype.Phenotype: Increased familial aggregation of breast cancer cases associated with ATM mutations
Evidence: Carriers of certain ATM mutations were found to have a higher frequency of early-onset breast cancer compared to non-carriers.

Percentages.Breast Cancer: 60% cumulative risk by age 80 for specific high-risk ATM variants

Evidence: In family-based analyses, the maximum-likelihood estimate of the increased risk was hazard ratio (HR) = 6.88 (95% CI, 2.33 to 20.3; P = 0.00008).

Recommendations: Enhanced breast cancer screening for carriers of high-risk ATM variants.
Consideration of risk-reducing mastectomy for specific high-risk individuals.
Evidence: Carriers of pathogenic ATM variants may require intensified surveillance similar to BRCA2 carriers.
Annual MRIs and mammograms are recommended for high-risk ATM mutation carriers starting at age 30.
Recommended starting at age 30 for high-risk ATM mutation carriers.

Age_Range_of_Management.Breast_Cancer: Starting at age 30 or earlier based on family history

Comments: The ATM c.7271T>G mutation is associated with a high penetrance of breast cancer and may require BRCA-level surveillance protocols.
Evidence_for_Cancer: Recent meta-analyses support that ATM mutations elevate breast cancer risk, particularly in specific pathogenic variants.
ATM mutations are associated with disrupted DNA damage repair pathways, increasing cancer susceptibility.

Therapeutic_Implications.Implications: Potential benefits of PARP inhibitors for ATM-mutated cancers, though more research is needed.
Evidence: DNA repair pathway-targeted therapies are being explored for patients with ATM-related cancers.

ACMG_Guidelines.Notes: Guidelines for including ATM mutations in genetic testing panels for hereditary breast cancer risk should be refined.

Paper_3.Title: Health risks for ataxia-telangiectasia mutated heterozygotes

Evidence: ATM mutation carriers have an increased risk of developing breast cancer (RRwomen 3.0, 95% CI 2.1–4.5), cancers of the digestive tract, and colorectal cancer.

Percentages.Breast Cancer: 3x increased risk for female ATM mutation carriers

Evidence: Based on meta-analysis, female carriers of the ATM c.7271T>G mutation show a significantly elevated breast cancer risk.
ATM heterozygotes have a relative risk of colorectal cancer of 2.54 (95% CI: 1.06–6.09).

Recommendations: Breast cancer screening starting at 25 years for high-risk ATM mutation carriers.
Evidence: All female ATM c.7271T>G mutation carriers from 25 years of age onwards should be offered intensified surveillance programs for breast cancer.

Recommendations: Colonoscopy every 5 years starting at age 40 for colorectal cancer risk management.
Evidence: Colonoscopy surveillance is recommended for colorectal cancer risk in ATM mutation carriers.

Frequency_of_Management.Frequency: Annual for breast cancer, every 5 years for colorectal cancer
Evidence: Annual MRIs for breast cancer, and 5-yearly colonoscopy for colorectal cancer in ATM mutation carriers.

Comments: ATM mutation carriers require tailored surveillance based on the specific cancer risks associated with the mutation subtype.

Therapeutic_Implications.Implications: Potential benefits of using targeted therapies like PARP inhibitors for ATM-related cancers.
Evidence: Emerging data suggest that ATM-related cancers may respond to DNA repair-targeting therapies.

Paper_4.Title: Incidence of cancer in ATM mutation carriers

Evidence: ATM carriers show a relative risk of breast cancer at 2.23 (95% CI: 1.16–4.28).
Colorectal cancer relative risk is estimated at 2.54 (95% CI: 1.06–6.09).

Clinical_Additional_Phenotype.Phenotype: Increased incidence of breast and colorectal cancers
Evidence: ATM mutation carriers are at moderate risk for specific cancers, with relative risks exceeding those of the general population.

Percentages.Breast Cancer: 2.23x increased risk for female ATM mutation carriers.
Percentages.Colorectal Cancer: 2.54x increased risk for ATM mutation carriers.

Evidence: Risk estimates are based on analyses of familial cancer cohorts and population-based studies.

Recommendations: Annual mammograms and MRIs starting at age 30 for high-risk ATM mutation carriers.
Evidence: Screening programs tailored for moderate-risk individuals may benefit ATM carriers.

Recommendations: Colonoscopy every 5 years starting at age 40 for colorectal cancer risk management.
Evidence: Increased colorectal cancer risk warrants routine surveillance in carriers.

Therapeutic_Implications.Implications: Potential utility of targeted therapies for ATM mutation-related cancers.
Evidence: Emerging research on DNA repair-targeting therapies indicates potential benefits for ATM mutation-associated malignancies.

Paper_5.Title: Meta-analysis of ATM mutations and cancer risks

Evidence: Meta-analysis supports elevated breast cancer risk with a relative risk of 2.3.
Lung cancer risks associated with ATM are less definitive but show moderate elevation.

Clinical_Additional_Phenotype.Phenotype: Varied cancer risk spectrum in ATM mutation carriers
Evidence: Elevated risks for specific cancer types are noted, with breast cancer being the most well-established.

Percentages.Breast Cancer: 2.3x increased risk for ATM mutation carriers.
Percentages.Lung Cancer: Moderate increase, specific risk estimates are not definitive.

Evidence: Risk estimates are derived from aggregated data across multiple familial and population-based studies.

Recommendations: Annual MRI and mammogram screening starting at age 30.
Evidence: Early detection strategies recommended for moderate-risk mutation carriers.
No specific management strategies identified.

Therapeutic_Implications.Implications: Further research is needed to explore targeted therapies for ATM-related lung cancer.
Evidence: Insights into ATM-related cancer pathways could lead to novel therapeutic strategies.
